title: Daisy Junor
text:
Daisy Junor ["nee" Knezovich] (July 10, 1919 – April 29, 2012) was a Canadian <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> who played in the <a href="All-American%20Girls%20Professional%20Baseball%20League">All-American Girls Professional Baseball League</a>. Listed at 5' 6", 140 lb., she batted and threw <a href="left-handed">left-handed</a>.
Basically a line-drive hitter and a fine defensive player, outfielder Daisy Junor was one of the fifty seven girls from Canada who played in the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League during its 12-year history. Her elder sister, <a href="Ruby%20Knezovich">Ruby Knezovich</a>, also played in the league.
Daisy was one of four children born into the family of Chris and Marina Knezovich. She was born and raised in <a href="Regina%2C%20Saskatchewan">Regina</a> and lived her entire life in the province of <a href="Saskatchewan">Saskatchewan</a>, with the exception of many winters she spent with her spouse Dave Junor in <a href="Mesa%2C%20Arizona">Mesa, Arizona</a>.
Basically a <a href="Glossary%20of%20baseball%20%28L%29%23line%20drive">line-drive</a> hitter and speedy <a href="Base%20running">base runner</a>, Junor was also a fine defensive player at all three outfield positions, playing mainly as a <a href="center%20fielder">center fielder</a> for three different teams during her four seasons in the league.
She entered the league in 1946 with the <a href="South%20Bend%20Blue%20Sox">South Bend Blue Sox</a>, playing for them two and a half years before joining the <a href="Springfield%20Sallies">Springfield Sallies</a> (1948) and the <a href="Fort%20Wayne%20Daisies">Fort Wayne Daisies</a> (1949). Her most productive season came in her <a href="rookie">rookie</a> year, when she posted career-highs in games played (99), <a href="Run%20%28baseball%29">runs</a> (30), <a href="Hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a> (60), <a href="run%20batted%20in">RBIs</a> (22) and <a href="stolen%20base">stolen base</a>s (41), while ranking 10th among all outfielders with 17 <a href="Assist%20%28baseball%29">assists</a>.
After returning to Regina, Junor became an accomplished <a href="Bowler%20%28ten-pin%29">bowler</a> and <a href="golf">golf</a>er. From there, she was a member of the provincial bowling team that represented Saskatchewan in the Western Canada Five Pin Bowling Championships three times, winning both city and provincial titles. In addition, she won five golf club championships, two city championships and a provincial senior ladies golf title.
In 1988, Junor received further recognition when she became part of "Women in Baseball", a permanent display based at the <a href="Baseball%20Hall%20of%20Fame%20and%20Museum">Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum</a> in <a href="Cooperstown%2C%20New%20York">Cooperstown, New York</a>, which was unveiled to honor the entire All-American Girls Professional Baseball League.
During her life, she was also honoured several times in recognition of her outstanding contribution to sport regionally, nationally and internationally, gaining inductions into the Saskatchewan Sports Hall of Fame (1989), the Canadian Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum (1998), the Regina Sports Hall of Fame (2004), and the Saskatchewan Baseball Hall of Fame in North Battleford.
Shortly before her death in 2012, the City of Regina honoured Daisy with the naming of Junor Drive in northwest Regina.
